SENT.plain: Hypertensive encephalopathy is a neurologic syndrome caused by a marked and rapid rise of blood pressure above baseline levels
Efficacy of current anti-hypertensive drugs greatly diminished the frequency of this situation in which diagnosis is essentially based on clinical parameters
This can justify the few papers found in radiologic literature
Nevertheless it is sometimes important to exclude ischemic or hemorrhagic complications or establish a differential diagnosis with other neuropathologic conditions
Then a striking imagiologic picture of focal or diffuse reversible edema of cerebral white matter can be found
We present three clinical cases of hypertensive encephalopathy
Imagiologic findings are reviewed and correlated with the pathophysiologic basis of the disease
